sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Bacteremia associated with intravascular line: (MRSA) 6 to 8 mg/kg IV once daily (guideline dosing)
  • Bacteremia associated with intravascular line: (methicillin-resistant, coagulase-negative staphylococci; ampicillin-resistant, vancomycin-susceptible Enterococcus faecalis/faecium; or ampicillin- and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecalis/faecium) 6 mg/kg IV once daily (guideline dosing)
  • Bacteremia due to Staphylococcus aureus, Including right-sided endocarditis: 6 mg/kg IV every 24 hours for 2 to 6 weeks (manufacturer dosing)
  • Bacteremia due to Staphylococcus aureus, Including right-sided endocarditis: 6 mg/kg IV every 24 hours for at least 2 weeks in uncomplicated infections or for 4 to 6 weeks in complicated infections; higher doses of 8 to 10 mg/kg IV every 24 hours recommended by some experts (guideline dosing)
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Complicated: 4 mg/kg IV once every 24 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Osteomyelitis: 6 to 8 mg/kg IV
  • Septic arthritis: (MRSA) 6 mg/kg IV once daily for 3 to 4 weeks (guideline dosing)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy in pediatric patients not established; avoid use in infants under the age of 12 months

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Hepatic impairment, mild to moderate: Adjustments not required
  • Renal impairment, complicated skin and skin structure infections, CrCl less than 30 mL/min: 4 mg/kg IV once every 48 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Renal impairment, Staphylococcus aureus bloodstream infections, CrCl less than 30 mL/min: 6 mg/kg IV once every 48 hours for 2 to 6 weeks
  • Hemodialysis, complicated skin and skin structure infections: 4 mg/kg IV once every 48 hours following hemodialysis on hemodialysis days for 7 to 14 days (manufacturer dosing) OR give dose 3 times a week coinciding with each dialysis session, with an additional 50% of the dose when the interdialytic period will be 72 hours. A dosage increase may also be warranted with intradialytic administration during the final 30 minutes of the session (study dose).
  • Hemodialysis, S aureus bloodstream infections: 6 mg/kg IV once every 48 hours following hemodialysis on hemodialysis days for 2 to 6 weeks (manufacturer dosing) OR give dose 3 times a week coinciding with each dialysis session, with an additional 50% of the dose when the interdialytic period will be 72 hours. A dosage increase may also be warranted with intradialytic administration during the final 30 minutes of the session (study dose).
  • Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis, complicated skin and skin structure infections: 4 mg/kg IV once every 48 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis, S aureus bloodstream infections: 6 mg/kg IV once every 48 hours for 2 to 6 weeks
  • Continuous venovenous hemodialysis: 8 mg/kg IV every 48 hours resulted in adequate peak levels without accumulation

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Bacteremia associated with intravascular line
  • Bacteremia due to Staphylococcus aureus, Including right-sided endocarditis
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue, Complicated
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Septic arthritis

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea has been reported; discontinuation may be necessary
  • Renal:
  • -- Decreased efficacy in patients with moderate baseline renal impairment
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Anaphylaxis and hypersensitivity reactions have been reported; discontinue if suspected
  • Musculoskeletal:
  • -- CPK elevations have occurred, especially in patients with renal impairment; monitoring recommended and discontinuation may be necessary
  • -- Myopathy and rhabdomyolysis have been reported; monitoring recommended and discontinuation may be necessary
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Peripheral neuropathy has been reported; monitoring recommended and discontinuation may be necessary
  • Respiratory:
  • -- Eosinophilic pneumonia may occur with possibility of reoccurrence with second exposure; discontinue and administer steroids if condition develops
  • Other:
  • -- Avoid us in pediatric patients younger than 12 months; risk of potential effects on the muscular, neuromuscular, peripheral nervous, or central nervous systems
  • -- Staphylococcus aureus infections that are persisting or relapsing may occur

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (5.2% to 11.7%), Vomiting (3.2% to 11.7%)
  • Respiratory:Pain in throat (8.3%)
Serious
  • Musculoskeletal:Rhabdomyolysis
  • Renal:Renal failure (2.2% to 3.3%)
  • Respiratory:Asthmatic pulmonary eosinophilia
  • Other:Disease due to Gram-negative bacteria (8.3%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Daptomycin binds to bacterial cell membranes and causes cell death by inducing rapid depolarization of the membrane potential, leading to disruption of DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis

1.title: Distribution
1.mono:
• Protein binding, primarily albumin: 90% to 93%
  • Protein binding, renal impairment: 83.5% to 87.6%
  • Vd: 0.1 L/kg
  • Vd, endocarditis and bacteremia: 0.21 L/kg
  • Vd, renal impairment: 0.12 to 0.20 L/kg

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Renal clearance: 0.05 to 0.1 mL/min/kg
  • Renal: 78% unchanged
  • Fecal: 5.7% unchanged
  • Dialyzable: Yes (hemodialysis), 15% over 4 hr; Yes (peritoneal), 11% over 4 hr
  • Total body clearance: 8.3 to 9.1 mL/hr/kg
  • Total body clearance, renal impairment: 5.9 to 9.9 mL/hr/kg
  • Total body clearance, hemodialysis and continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis: 3.7 mL/hr/kg

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• 7.7 to 8.3 hr
  • Severe renal impairment (CrCl less than 30 mL/min), 27.83 hr
  • Hemodialysis and continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis, 19.4 to 45.5 hr

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • Reconstitute 500-mg vial with 10 mL of NS; administer dose either as an IV injection over 2 minutes or further dilute in 50 mL NS and administer as an IV infusion over 30 minutes
  • Do not mix with additives or other medications or infuse simultaneously through the same IV line
  • Do not use ReadyMED(R) elastomeric infusion pumps (Cardinal Health, Inc) to store or deliver daptomycin doses; mercaptobenzothiazole (MBT) has been detected in drug samples tested from these pumps
  • Compatible with NS and LR; incompatible with dextrose-containing solutions

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• fever
  • CBC
  • symptomatic improvement
  • liver function tests
  • repeat blood cultures; in patients with persistent or relapsing Staphylococcus aureus infection or poor clinical response
  • serum CPK levels, weekly; more frequently in patients with prior or concomitant therapy with an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor, in patients with renal insufficiency, or in patients who develop unexplained elevations in CPK
  • signs and symptoms of neuropathy
  • symptoms of muscle pain/weakness, especially in distal extremities

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause constipation, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, headache, insomnia, dyspnea, or rhabdomyolysis (myalgias, dark urine, arthralgias, fatigue).
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of neuropathy.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of muscle pain/weakness, especially in distal extremities.
  • Patient should report diarrhea and consult healthcare professional prior to taking anti-diarrhea medicine.
  • Instruct patient to avoid using HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors (cholesterol lowering agents such as atorvastatin, fluvastatin, lovastatin, simvastatin) unless approved by healthcare professional, as concurrent use with daptomycin may increase risk of myopathy.
